title: Enum raw values
question: Which of these statements about enums with raw values are true?
hint: Raw values let us give each of our enum cases a value so they are more than just names.

correct.answer: Raw values let us give meaning to enum cases.
correct.reason: They let us say that earth has an underlying value of 3, for example.

correct.answer: Raw values let us create enum values dynamically.
correct.reason: We can create an enum from its raw value.

correct.answer: Integer raw values count from 0 automatically.
correct.reason: You can modify this to something specific if you want.

correct.answer: You can give each case specific values if you want.
correct.reason: This is optional, but it gives us fine-grained control when needed.

correct.answer: You can use integers for raw values.
correct.reason: Integers are one of the most common raw value types.

correct.answer: You don't need to use raw values.

wrong.answer: Raw values are required for enums.
Raw values can't be used directly.
wrong.reason: You can read them if you want, or create enum instances from them.

wrong.answer: If you give one case a value you must give them all values.
wrong.reason: Swift is able to infer values based on the ones you provide.

wrong.answer: Raw values make enums into dictionaries.
wrong.reason: Enums with raw values are still just enums.

wrong.answer: Raw values must always be strings.
wrong.reason: You can use something else if you wish, such as integers.

wrong.answer: Raw values and associated values are the same.
wrong.reason: Associated values attach extra data to an enum case; raw values are underlying data types for each case.
